subject: RE: [junit] A Growing Problem
msgSnippet: On Sun, 25 Aug 2002 20:03:12 -0400, STRAYER, JON (AIT) ... Not true.  You have problems that JUnit wasn t meant to solve... either design issues (can t UNIT!
messageBody:
On Sun, 25 Aug 2002 20:03:12 -0400, "STRAYER, JON (AIT)"
<jon.strayer@...> said:
> This message only has an HTML part -- this is a text generated
> representation
>
>
> >> And that JUnit fail after one test fails, so what? You want
> >> all tests to pass so if one fails, find it, fix your code,
> >> and go again.
> >
> > This can be a big problem in large systems that take minutes
> > (or longer) to compile and test. It's nice to get a complete
> > list of failures so that you can attempt to fix as many as
> > possible before having to dive into the build process again...
> If you have a large system that can't be tested in small doses
> then
> you have
> problems that JUnit can't solve.

Not true. You have problems that JUnit wasn't meant to solve... either
design issues (can't UNIT! test because things aren't written in such a
way to allow it -- better refactor and test a lot) or you are trying to
some sort of functional or interaction test (these can often times be
accomplished through JUnit, but its purpose it UNIT! level testing).

=jason
--
Jason Rogers
jacaetevha@...
